author: Special Correspondent
text:
Close on the heels of the announcement of the Assembly elections, Collector K.S.Palanisamy convened a meeting with representatives of political parties on Saturday to brief them about the model code of conduct.

Listing out the dos and don’ts for political parties and candidates, he told the party representatives to ensure that all their wall writings, flags, banners and hoardings were removed within three days. Otherwise they would be removed by the authorities and the expenditure would be included in the candidates’ expenditure account.

Political parties should desist from personal attacks and on the basis of caste. Places of worship should not be used for campaigning. Temporary election offices should not be situated near schools, college and hospitals. Permission should be obtained for all vehicles used by political parties from the Collector and vehicles without permission would be seized. Permission should be obtained for public meetings and the meetings should be conducted without causing obstruction to traffic.

Permission should be obtained from election-related advertisements from the Media Monitoring Committee headed by the Collector. Campaigning should be wound up by 10 p.m. and cone loud speakers should not be used. Complaints with respect to distribution of cash or articles can also be lodged over the toll free number 18004257030, he said.

E.S.Uma, District Superintendent of Police, K.Tharpagaraj, District Revenue Officer, and representatives of various political parties attended the meeting.
title: Dos and don’ts for political parties and candidates
